OK FOODS, Inc.

Fort Smith, Arkansas





RISK MANAGMENT PLAN

Executive Summary





1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



OK. Foods, utilize anhydrous ammonia in a closed-circuit refrigeration system. O.K. Foods established; programs, procedures and safety devices to prevent exposure to personnel, community and surrounding environment also protect property assets. Policies have been created to comply with all Federal, State, and Local regulations. O.K. Foods strives to prevent potential releases through continual, training and evaluation of policies, programs and procedures.  



Emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies. Working in conjunction with the Fort Smith Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all affected neighbors.





2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The primary purpose of the facility is the processing of poultry products. Utilizing one regulated substance above the threshold level:  anhydrous ammonia.



Anhydrous ammonia is used as the primary means for refrigeration, cooling and freezing. An outside company is used to fill our main receiver tanks.  Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration, cooling or freezing units. Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 



O.K. Foods has three independent systems at this site. The largest and only 'covered' process contains 81,078 pounds of ammonia.  The total amount of ammonia stored at this facility is 92,761 pounds.  



3. THE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO(S) AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO(S), INCLUDING ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO LIMIT THE DISTANCES FOR EACH REPORTED SCENARIO





Worst Case Scenario (endpoint based on RMP*Comp; population from MARPLOT)



The worst case scenario for this

facility has been determined to be a release of 19,902 pounds of ammonia from the high pressure receiver.  The rule requires the assumption that the entire contents of the largest vessel, or the vessel with the furthest endpoint impact, without management controls, are released within 10 minutes as a two phase flow.  O.K. Foods has determined that the Plant 2 receiver to be the source of the worst-case release.  The actual largest vessel is the 34,000-lb intercooler.  However, this vessel is liquid by refrigeration under vacuum and is located indoors.  A release under the same scenario conditions has a toxic endpoint of only 0.1 miles.   

Distance to endpoint: 1.7 miles

Population: 13,067



Alternative Scenarios (endpoints based on RMP*Comp; population from 

MARPLOT)



All 5 alternative scenarios identified in 68.28(b)(2) were considered and are summarized here.  

(i.)    Delivery truck transfer line failure at the Plant 2 receiver.

a.    Toxic endpoint distance = 0.3 miles

b.    Population affected = 1,059

(ii.)    Process piping failure (1" pipe inside Plant 2).

a.    Toxic endpoint = 0.3 miles

b.    Population affected = 1, 059

(iii.)    Release from hole in Plant 2 receiver

a.    Toxic endpoint 0.8 miles

b.    Population affected = 4,555 and 3 elementary schools

(iv.)    1" high pressure relief valve release from Plant 2

a.    Toxic endpoint = 0.4 miles

b.    Population affected = 1,257

(v.)    Vapor leak from an 8 in2 hole in an un-liquefied container inside Plant 2.

a.    Toxic endpoint = 0.3 miles

b.    Population affected = 1,059

Scenario (iv.) is considered by the O.K. Foods Process Safety Committee as being the most likely to occur.



4. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



This O.K. Foods facility has not had a reportable accident in the last five years. 





5. THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



OK Foods RMP program use outside entities or organizations including the Sebastian County Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Fort Smith Fire Department and HAZMAT team.





6. THE GENER

AL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



OK Foods facility complies with all applicable Federal, State and Local regulations including the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule. All personnel are trained about this during our Hazard Communications Training and through access to our Written Programs. Maintenance and Refrigeration operators receive On-The-Job (OTJ) training. They are observed by senior maintenance staff and are able to demonstrate proper job

skills and knowledge.





7. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



OK Foods work closely with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Fort Smith Fire Department and HAZMAT team on emergency preparedness. Periodically meetings are conducted to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns.  





8. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Currently, OK Foods trains and tests all refrigeration technicians. Process Safety Management Program is reviewed and updated annually also the program is improved continuously through annual updates of our written program and annual training of our technicians.  We also take advantage of new technologies that are available.
